CTR.Q: What type of chart is this?

VEC.Q: How many ridgelines are in this ridgeline chart?
VEC.A: There are {6} slices in this chart.

SRP.Q: What is the spatial relationship of the peak of Tidal relative to the peak of Geothermal in terms of vertical (above/below) and horizontal (left/right) directions?
SRP.A: The peak of  Tidal is to the {left} of the peak of Geothermal.

VPR.Q: What distribution pattern does the ridgeline representing Hybrid Systems show?
VPR.A: The ridgeline representing Hybrid Systems shows a {Single Peak Distribution}.

VPR.Q: At what value do  Solar reach its peaks?

EVJ.Q: Which ridgeline has the highest peak
EVJ.A: The ridgeline representing {Tidal} has the highest peak.

EVJ.Q: Which label has the highest density at X =46.0?
EVJ.A: At X =46.0,the label with the highest density is {Hydroelectric}

NF.Q: Which countries in the ridgeline chart have ridgeline peaks exceed 36? Please list the countries and corresponding peak values.
NF.A: {Wind}'s peak at {84},{Solar}'s peak at {86},{Hydroelectric}'s peak at {85}

NF.Q: Which countries in the ridgeline chart have ridgeline peaks below 31? Please list the countries and corresponding peak values.
NF.A: {Hybrid Systems}'s peak at {9},{Geothermal}'s peak at {13},{Tidal}'s peak at {11}

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Wind or Tidal?
NC.A: {Wind} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Tidal or Hybrid Systems?
NC.A: {Tidal} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Solar or Wind?
NC.A: {Solar} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

MSR.Q: How many ridges have their peak located to the right of the average X value across all ridges?
MSR.A: There are {3} ridges whose peaks are located to the right of the average X value.

MSR.Q: What is the label of the ridge with the largest span along the mountain height?
MSR.A: The ridge with the largest span in the mountain height is {Tidal}
